title: Rolling Stones superfan lands original copy of band’s first contract
text:
This is one epic collection ahead (Picture: Chris Tuite/imageSPACE/REX)

We all want to care about things, but the superfan goes to lengths that far surpass the regular fan.

For eons we’ve worshipped at the altars of sports stars, pop stars, actors, fictional characters, collectables, art, cars, and just about anything else we can relate to, that we can buy, that we can love and share with others.

Also known as a ‘fanatic’ (but, let’s face it, ‘fan’ is much more sexy), these superfans have travelled the globe to support their chosen love, spent hundreds of thousands on merchandise, altered their body in dramatic ways, some have even changed their names – and we’ve tracked down the most die-hard and dedicated to telling their story.

Each week we’ll bring you the story of one keen punter who has dedicated their life and time (and money, so.much.money) to supporting someone or something – simply because it brings them immeasurable joy.

Advertisement

Advertisement

And that’s what life’s about, right?

Say hi to Metro.co.uk’s super fun superfan series, I’m Your Biggest Fan.

Matt Lee is probably the world’s biggest collector of Rolling Stones memorabilia, and that’s saying something.

For more than 30 years he’s been gathering the very best of merch from the legendary band’s history.

Matt Lee has seen ol’ mate Mick Jagger thousands of times (Picture: Matt Lee)

With a collection worthy of its own museum exhibition, not only is he attempting to break the Guinness World Record for the having the largest collection, the 44-year-old Londoner is currently working with Rebel Vision as they tour an immersive concert screening of The Rolling Stones iconic Havana Moon gig around the UK.

As the Secretary of Rock & Roll for The Havana Moon tour (quite the title), he lends his amazing attention to detail to the production and dressing of the show, including the set design and merchandise.

Seeing as he’s travelled all around the world and gone to thousands of shows, he’s the man for the job.

So, when did you first, first get into The Rolling Stones and what dragged you in?

He has all access, and he’s giving us an insight (Picture: Matt Lee)

When I was 12-years-old, my father gave me a cassette tape of Solid Rock, a Rolling Stones compilation album. The cowbell at the beginning of Honky Tonk Women, the opening track, really made an impact on me. I soon got a drum kit to try to play it myself. Now I have several actual drum sticks thrown into the crowd by Charlie Watts at the end of concerts.

He even has a copy of the band’s original contract (Picture: Matt Lee)

Then, in 1995, I went to my first Rolling Stones concert. It was Sunday, 16 July, at Wembley Stadium.

Advertisement

Advertisement

I was a student and had a CD player by then and half of my collection were Stones CDs. But after that concert I started buying more. A year later, at university in America, you could get CDs for four of five dollars, so I could buy an album for £2.50-3.50. In the UK, they were still selling them for £15. CDs over there were cheap, even for a student in America.

When did it become more of an obsession and collection?

It never has been an obsession, but it is most definitely a passion! When I moved back to the UK from America, that’s when I started collecting Rolling Stones posters and trading them with other collectors around the world.

Just a couple of items (Picture: Matt Lee)

Can you count how many? (Picture: Matt Lee)

In 1998, the UK tour was postponed. I bought loads of posters from the cancelled shows and started trading them for other shows around the world. There’s a legendary status of posters from cancelled shows, starting from the famous cancelled Cardiff show in 1973 (and Budokan, also in 1973.) Even today I’m mainly a poster collector, or a collector of visual artwork in general. In 2000, my collection was showcased in a front-cover feature in Record Collector magazine.

How has that love for the band and collecting changed over the years?

It hasn’t really changed, but it gets harder and harder to find good stuff. Plus I’m more selective because I have so much stuff. I don’t really collect just anything these days. I want a piece to enhance the collection.

Advertisement

If you’ve got a 1960s gig poster, I’ll come see it. I’d fly anywhere for the right stuff.

Just a few of his many, many ticket stubs (Picture: Matt Lee)

My quality threshold has gone up. Before, when I didn’t have very much, I’d buy lots of things. But now I really only want the best stuff.

How much do you think you’ve spent on merch over the years?

A lot.

Ha, alright then. What’s the most expensive item you’ve bought?

My most valuable item is the Rolling Stones’ first contract that Brian Jones signed on behalf of the band.

He’s now helping the Havana Moon immersive tour (Picture: Matt Lee)

It’s currently on loan for the Rolling Stones’ world-touring Exhibitionism.

Charlie Watts said at the opening in London in 2016 that the contract was the ‘most poignant’ item in the exhibition.

How many items do you think you have?

I have tens of thousands of pieces, from commercially available merchandise to rare or one-off items like hand-written lyrics, setlists and promotional items.

Do you think anyone comes close, or you might be in line to get the world record?

There are several people around the world with great Rolling Stones collections. Some of them specialise in certain areas, like posters or albums. I like to collect rare, one-of-a-kind items. I’m going for the Guinness World Record for the largest Rolling Stones collection on 14 November.

This is enough to make a grown man cry! (Picture: Matt Lee)

He’s attempting to break the world record (Picture: Matt Lee)

If you could, what would name as your prized possession?

Advertisement

My first tour laminate in 2007, which I got as a guest of Ronnie Wood and allowed me to attend any show I wanted.

I also literally bought a shirt off the back of one of the event staff at the free concert in Havana in 2016. I’ll be wearing it to the Havana Moon screenings. That may be my quirkiest find.

What do your friends make of your collection?

The Stones fans ask a lot of questions about it and seem to enjoy seeing the items, especially the rare ones. But it kind of inspires a lot of people. Even non-Stones fans think it’s pretty impressive and ask lots of questions about it.

We have to ask, where do you keep everything?

I have a room in my flat where I have a mini-museum with lots of things in display cases. I am planning on opening a bigger “museum” soon in a dedicated commercial space near my flat. Plus I have multiple storage units.

Million dollar question, what do the Stones themselves think?

I don’t know how much they know about it, but they are all welcome to come by and see it for themselves.

The Havana Moon tour culminates at London’s Kentish Town Forum on Sunday 27 October. For remaining tour dates and ticket information, visit www.rebel-vision.com.
